Fig 11 Review Two-dimensional organic cathode materials for alkali-metal-ion batteries Chao Zhang a Chenbao Lu a Fan Zhang a Feng Qiu b Xiaodong Zhuang a ⁎ Xinliang Feng c ⁎ a Shanghai Key Lab of Electrical Insulation and Thermal Ageing, Shanghai Electrochemical Energy Devices Research Center, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China Shanghai Key Lab of Electrical Insulation and Thermal Ageing, Shanghai Electrochemical Energy Devices Research Center, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 China b School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai 201418, China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Shanghai Institute of Technology Shanghai 201418 China c Department of Chemistry and Food Chemistry, Center for Advancing Electronics Dresden (cfaed), Technische Universität Dresden, 01062 Dresden, Germany Department of Chemistry and Food Chemistry Center for Advancing Electronics Dresden (cfaed), Technische Universität Dresden Dresden 01062 Germany ⁎ Corresponding authors. With the increasing demand for large-scale battery systems in electric vehicles (EVs) and smart renewable energy grids, organic materials including small molecules and polymers utilized as electrodes in rechargeable batteries have received increasing attraction. In recent years, two-dimensional (2D) organic materials possessing planar layered architecture exhibit optional chemical modification, high specific surface area as well as unique electrical/magnetic properties, which have been emerging as the promising functional materials for wide applications in optoelectronics, catalysis, sensing, etc. Integrating with high-density redox-active sites and hierarchical porous structure, significant achievements in 2D organic materials as cathode materials for alkali-metal-ion batteries have been witnessed. In this review, the recent progress in synthetic approaches, structure analyses, electrochemical characterizations of 2D organic materials as well as their application in alkali-metal-ion batteries containing lithium ion battery (LIB), lithium sulfur battery (LSB), lithium air battery (LAB) and sodium ion battery (SIB) are summarized systematically, and their current challenges including cycling stability and electron conductivity for cathode materials in battery fields are also discussed. Graphical abstract Three types of two-dimensional (2D) organic materials with great potential as cathodes for alkali-metal-ion batteries were summarized in this review. Both of preparation methods and structure features of such 2D organic cathodes were briefly introduced. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Organic material Two-dimensional Cathode Alkali-metal-ion battery 1 Introduction The technology of energy storage and conversion lights up various electronic devices, giving the comfortable life in modern society [1–4]. Electrochemical energy storage is considered as one of the most promising strategies for storing energy [3,5–7]. With the development of nanotechnology, the appropriate energy storage devices, including fuel cells [8–11], rechargeable alkali-metal-ion batteries [12–19] and supercapacitors [20–22], etc., have been designed rationally. Among them, rechargeable alkali-metal-ion batteries, featuring clean, portable and high energy density characters, have attracted much attention in the field of chemistry and material science [18,23,24]. For alkali-metal-ion batteries, the electrode materials are the one of most important component parts, yet they often suffer from short cycle life, slow charging-discharging rate and lower power density, which limits their wide applications in electric vehicles and smart renewable energy grids [25,26]. Thus, design and construction of electrode materials with controllable nanostructure is still the main challenge to gain high-performance alkali-metal-ion batteries [27–30]. The electrode materials in alkali-metal-ion batteries can be divided into negative electrode and positive electrode, termed anode and cathode, respectively. For the former one, tunable porous carbon frameworks decorated with metal oxides and metal sulfides as the anode materials exhibit high reversible capacity, long cycle life, and rate performance in the recent years [18,31–33]. On the other hand, layered lithium transition metal oxides represent the most successful category of cathode, e.g. LiCoO2 or LiFePO4, which can undergo oxidation to higher valences when lithium is removed [34–38]. However, the complex preparation methods with energy consuming and low cycling performance severely restricted the practical applications of these inorganic cathode materials [39,40]. Therefore, that the development of cathode materials could not reach to match with that of anode is the critical problem to construct high performance alkali-metal-ion batteries. Recently, two-dimensional (2D) materials, featuring ultrathin thickness of few atoms and large lateral size, exhibit excellent characters, such as large surface area, high mechanical strength, and amplified electronic and optical properties, which make them promising candidates in next-generation energy devices applications [41–45]. Compared with inorganic 2D materials, such as transition metal dichalcogenide [46–49], metal oxides [50,51], and metal hydroxides [52,53], 2D organic materials with reversible redox activity have been considered as novel cathode materials, due to their tunable structures, light weight, flexibility, and good semiconducting properties [42,54]. As the typical example of 2D organic materials, graphene, a flat monolayer of carbon atoms arranged in a 2D honeycomb lattice, exhibits unique physical and electronic properties, including high specific surface area, high mechanical strength, long distance conductivity, and good accessibility for electrolytes [42,55–60]. To date, large amounts of graphene-based composite materials have been developed as cathode materials for high-performance alkali-metal-ion batteries [54,61–66]. Feng et al. reported that the macroporous graphene aerogel-supported iron(III) hydroxide phosphate dihydrate microspheres (GA/IHPDs) hybrids showed the excellent ultrahigh current densities and reversible specific capacity of 155 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at a current density of 50 mA g−1. These intriguing results could be attributed to the synergistic interaction between the IHPD and the graphene aerogel, in which the graphene not only provided a continuous pathway for electron transportation, but also reduced the volume changes of the IHPD during the charge–discharge cycles [67]. Unfortunately, pristine graphene gives the zero bandgap and low electrochemical activity, leading to its poor specific capacity [68]. In this regard, searching for new 2D organic materials with high conductivity and reversible electrochemical activity as the alternative key cathode components for applications in alkali-metal-ion batteries is highly desirable. To meet the requirement of 2D organic materials as the cathode for the application in alkali-metal-ion batteries, incorporation of heteroatoms (e.g. boron (B), nitrogen (N), sulfur (S), phosphorus (P)) into the carbon backbone of 2D organic materials represents an efficient strategy to obtain high electrochemical performance for alkali-metal-ion batteries [69–72]. On the basis of efficient chemical synthesis, heteroatoms can be embedded into the frameworks of 2D organic materials with well-controlled architecture on molecule level by using appropriate building blocks and various linkages [73]. Over the past few decades, the remarkable achievements in design and synthesis of 2D heteroatom-embedded organic materials as cathode materials have been witnessed significantly. According to their structural size, these 2D organic materials can be classified as 2D polyaromatic molecules, 2D covalent organic frameworks, and 2D polymeric nanosheets. Considering the broad field of 2D organic materials, the construction and application of some branches of this field, like covalent organic frameworks (COFs), have been enough described in another review article [74–76]. However, a perspective review on the design of heteroatom-embedded 2D organic materials as cathode for the application in alkali-metal-ion batteries has not yet been documented so far. In this review, we will comprehensively summary the synthetic approaches, characterization, and electrochemical properties of heteroatom-embedded 2D organic materials as cathode materials in alkali-metal-ion batteries, including lithium ion battery, lithium sulfur battery, lithium air battery and sodium ion battery. The potential future directions of these 2D organic materials are also discussed. 2 2D polyaromatic molecules Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) with extended π-delocalized structure have been represented as typical two-dimensional graphene segments [77]. Because of their unique optoelectronic and electrochemical properties, these 2D polyaromatic molecules have gained increasing interest in the application of optoelectronic devices, such as organic field transistors (OFETs) [78], organic solar cells (OPVs) [79], and organic light-emitting devices (OLEDs) [80,81]. Concerning their facile synthetic protocols, incorporation of various redox functional groups into the aromatic frameworks of 2D polyaromatic molecules is an efficient strategy to endow their excellent electrochemical performance for energy storage and conversion. For alkali-metal-ion batteries, 2D polyaromatic molecules possessing a multi-stage redox ability have been used as cathode-active materials [82,83], termed “Molecular Crystalline Secondary Batteries” [84,85]. Moreover, the increasing of conductivity and the decreasing of solubility in battery electrolytes are also beneficial for these 2D polyaromatic molecules utilized as cathode materials. Thanks to the matched atom ratiometer and electronegativity, the nitrogen atom possessing a lone pair of electrons is a type of perfect element for building up various nitrogen-containing PAHs with reversible redox property, which have been extensively studied for the application in energy storage and conversion [86]. Loh et al. reported the synthesis of a fused N-heteroaromatic triquinoxalinylene (3Q) molecules by Schiff-base reaction between 1,2-diaminobenzene and cyclohexanehexone. This 3Q molecule exhibited good redox performance and fast charge transport, which was much suitable for cathode material in LIBs. In the charge/discharge profile of 3Q battery (Fig. 1 a), two clear pairs of reversible plateaux at about 2.6–2.15 V/2.11–2.95 V and 1.68–1.38 V/1.41–1.75 V was observed significantly, consisting with two reduction peaks during the cathodic CV scan (Fig. 1b). This result demonstrated the 3Q molecules had multiple redox reactions with highly reversible nature during the charging/discharging processes. Using 3Q molecule as cathode electrode, an initial discharge capacity about 395 mA h g−1 was achieved under a current density of 400 mA g−1. To gain insight into the lithium storage mechanism of 3Q, in situ NMR studies were performed to identify the structural changes associated with multiple electron transfer during battery operations. Due to the different coordination patterns of nitrogen atoms and lithium ions in the 3Q molecule, the local electronic environment of the electroactive N was expected to change dynamically during the lithiation and delithiation processes. 15N NMR results demonstrated the existence of five different 15N resonances, which was in accordance with the density functional theory (DFT) simulation of spin distribution on the equivalent pyrazine nitrogen (Fig. 1c). Recently, quinone molecules have been widely studied molecules for lithium-ion battery cathodes due to their two electron reduction, providing a high theoretical capacity (C theor) [88]. However, the high solubility of quinone in battery electrolytes and low conductivity would limit their application in commercial battery devices. Combining quinone with 2D polyaromatic structure, the high capacity of batteries was received. Takui et al. reported the design and synthesis of stable open-shell molecular systems applied for cathode-active materials. Authors found that tri‑tert‑butylated trioxotriangulene ((t-Bu)3TOT) and tri-bromide trioxotriangulene ((Br)3TOT) with an intensively spin delocalized nature exhibited high stable neutral radical. Through the weak interaction like π–π stacking, these 2D molecules could form one dimensional columnar supramolecular structures, which were favorable for providing a high cycle performance. Quantum chemical calculations for (t-Bu)3TOT and (Br)3TOT showed that the energy gaps between the SOMO and the degenerate LUMO are 0.82 and 0.56 V, respectively (Fig. 2 a). The CV of the (t-Bu)3TOT anion demonstrated a redox wave at −0.40 V and three waves with small potential gaps between −2 and −2.6 V with high reversibility (Fig. 2b). While, the CV of the (Br)3TOT anion showed an electrochemically irreversible wave around 0 V and three slight waves between −2 and −3.05 V. These wave shapes could be attributed to the low solubility of redox species formed in the redox process. In these TOT derivatives, the four redox waves were assigned to be redox stages relating to the SOMO and the LUMOs, respectively. Using (t-Bu)3TOT as a cathode-active material, the charge–discharge properties of coin-type cell measured at 0.3 C in the voltage range 1.4–3.8 V with the first capacity of 311 A h kg−1 (Fig. 2c). However, the discharge capacity of cell decreased gradually and the discharge capacity was 73 A h kg−1 after 100 cycles, which was 43% of the value at the second cycle, resulting from the composition of (t-Bu)3TOT. Compared with that of (t-Bu)3TOT, (Br)3TOT exhibited the first discharge capacity (225 A h kg−1), close to the theoretical one (192 A h kg−1). Meanwhile, the cycle performances of the discharge processes measured at 1 C and 2 C showed 159 and 177 A h kg−1 after 100 cycles, respectively, which was 71% and 85% of the first values, suggesting the extremely low solubility of (Br)3TOT in the electrolyte solution from its strong intermolecular interaction in the crystal structure (Fig. 2d). Besides quinones, other carbonyl-containing compounds, like carboxylic acid anhydrides [90–93] and amides [94], are also good choices for cathode electrodes, due to their high redox activity when carbonyl group was embedded on the 2D polyaromatic frameworks. Here, enolation reaction of carbonyl double bonds can be stabilized by conjugated structures, which makes it possible for Li ions to be inserted or deinserted reversibly at the positions of oxygen atoms when the carbonyl groups are reduced or oxidized. Thus, this kind of 2D polyaromatic molecules has been implied as novel cathode electrodes for alkali-metal-ion batteries. As example of 3,4,9,10-perylene-tetracarboxylic acid-dianhydride (PTCDA), each carbonyl group can receive one electron and insert one Li ion to form lithium enolate in the reduction process, while the Li ions were deinserted in the reverse oxidation process (Fig. 3 a). The perylene ring formed a conjugated structure with the carbonyl groups could promote this reaction above. Thus, PTCDA possessed the high theoretical capacity of 273 A h kg–1, based on the mechanism of four active lithiation sites in PTCDA (Fig. 3b). PTCDAs were also proved to be practical in cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries [91] and potassium-ion batteries [93], and exhibited comparable performance in these fields. However, PTCDA showed the poor cycling stability, in which the capacity was decreased gradually with the increasing of cycling number (Fig. 3c). In contrast, the higher capacity was expected without loss of stability by using 1,4,5,8-naphthalene tetracarboxylicacid-dianhydride (NTCDA) as the cathode, which had the simliar structure to PTCDA (Fig. 3d). Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have received increasing attention, owing to their high theoretical capacity (1672 mA h g−1), cost effectiveness and environmental friendliness. Unfortunately, the poor cyclability hampers their commercial application, originating from the shuttle of dissolved lithium polysulfide (LiPS) intermediates into electrolyte. Recently, fully sulfur-substituted 2D PAHs carrying fused disulfide bonds at the periphery have been regarded as potential cathode material, due to their excellent redox behavior and promising charge transport properties. Feng et al. reported the synthesis of 2D persulfurated coronene with an all-sulfur terminated edge structure (PSC 5), which exhibited sulfur-rich feature, redox behavior as well as low solubility in most organic electrolyte, making it possible to perform an excellent Li–S battery performance. The result demonstrated the first discharge–charge voltage profiles of PSC 5 measured at 0.6 C in the potential range of 1–3 V versus Li/Li+ (Fig. 4 a), in which PSC 5 displayed only one plateau at ∼2.0 V after the first cycle, proposing the one-electron transfer process for the formation of LiS complexes. The PSC 5-based LIB exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 424 mA h g−1 and an exceptional initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 85%, which was well comparable with that of reported S8-encapsulated and organic-based matrix/sulfur composites cathodes [95–100]. Moreover, compound PSC 5 had stable cycling performance. The capacity of 520 A h kg−1 was retained after 120 cycles and Coulombic efficiency of 90% was displayed at 0.6 C (Fig. 4b). 3 2D covalent organic frameworks Conjugated polymers, integrating the advantages of polyaromatic molecules and conventional polymers, have been well developed and exhibited tremendous properties, inculding high charge transfer and redox activity, due to their extended π-delocalized electronic structure. In addition, these conjugated polymers are also stable and have low solubility into organic electrolyte [101,102]. Thus, conjugated polymers have been allowed to be constructed into electrodes with high electrochemical performance [70,103]. Combined with unique character of anisotropic electrical properties as well as high specific surface area in 2D morphology, 2D conjugated polymers can be optimized as cathode for high-performance alkali-metal-ion batteries. COFs are a class of crystalline organic conjugated porous materials using π-π stacking interactions as a driving force and reversible chemical bonds as linkages [74]. 2D COFs hold the crystallization of polygonal sheets with in-plane conjugated periodic frameworks and ordered pores [75]. Using redox-activity anthraquinones (DAAQ) as building block, Wang et al. reported the synthesis of 2D DAAQ-TFP-COF with β-ketoenamine-linkage, obtained by polycondensation of 2,6-diaminoanthraquinone (DAAQ) and 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol (TFP) under solvothermal conditions (Fig. 5 a). After exfoliated the pristine redox-active COFs into few-layer nanosheets with thicknesses of 3–5 nm, utilization efficiency of redox sites in exfoliated DAAQ-TFP-ECOF was improved for lithium storage by shortening the Li+ diffusion pathways. In DAAQ-TFP-ECOF, there were two steps (AQ/AQ•− and AQ•−/AQ2−, Fig. 5b) involved in the electrochemical redox reaction and even more steps in a conjugated structure. Cyclic voltammogram (CV) results demonstrated that DAAQ-TFP-ECOFs exhibited highly reversible lithiation/delithiation reactions with a pair of symmetric redox peaks at 2.34 and 2.48 V [104], which was comparable with many emerging cathode materials, such as Prussian blue analogs (2–3 V), sulfur (∼2.1 V). The reduction potential of DAAQ-TFP-ECOFs at 0.4 V was higher than that of the monomer DAAQ, resulting from the extended conjugation within the 2D polymeric layer [105] (Fig. 5c). Thus, DAAQ-TFP-ECOF produced the small gap between these redox potentials and resulted in a sloping curve in charge/discharge experiments (Fig. 5d) [106]. The maximum capacity of 145 mA h g−1 at a rate of 20 mA g−1 was obtained by using DAAQ-TFP-ECOF as cathode material, and the rate performance of DAAQ-ECOF was 93, 89, 86, 74, 68, 60 mA h g−1 and 50% at increased current rates of 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000 and 3000 mA g−1, respectively. The capacity of DAAQ-TFP-ECOF was higher than those of DAAQ and DAAQ-TFP-COF, due to the rapid Li+ transport along the shortened diffusion paths with Li+ diffusion coefficient (DLi +) of 6.94 × 10−11 cm2 s−1 (Fig. 5e). Moreover, DAAQ-TFP-ECOF exhibited good cycling performance. The reversible capacity was retained at 104 mA h g−1 after 1800 cycles, with a mild activation process during the initial several cycles possibly due to the penetration of electrolyte (Fig. 5f). To introdce redox activated groups (Fig. 6 a) into COFs and improve the conductivity of COFs, Jiang and coworkers synthesized a novel redox-active COFs (DTP-ANDI-COF@CNTs) by in situ polycondensation of 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydoxytriphenylene and N,N′-di-(4-boronophenyl)-naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetracarboxylic acid diimide on CNT wires under solvothermal conditions (Fig. 6b) [71]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) results demonstrated the AA stacking lattice of DTP-ANDI-COF with ordered mesoporous channels were retained in the DTP-ANDI-COF@CNTs. In the CV profiles, two obvious peaks could be easily seen in solid black (DTP-ANDI-COF) and red one (DTP-ANDI-COF@CNTs) (Fig. 6c). By comparing DTP-ANDI-COF, the DTP-ANDI-COF@CNTs exhibited a smaller plateaux value of 0.19 V, indicating the increased conductivity of DTP-ANDI-COF@CNTs (Fig. 6c). Fig. 6(d) presented the discharge–charge curves recorded for LIBs with the DTP-ANDI-COF@CNTs as cathodes after 100 cycles at a rate of 2.4 C. The working potential was determined to be 2.4 V from the pseudo plateaus of the charge–discharge curves, which retained the shape of curves after 100 cycles, demonstrating its high energy-storage stability. In the cycling test, the capacity at 67 mA h g−1 corresponds to an efficiency of 82% was rather stable. The slightly increasing tendency of capacity during the initial five cycles was a result of the electrolyte penetration process. This excellent cycling performance was much better than monomer of PTCDI and PI as mentioned above, proving that integrating redox active sites into COFs with conductive carbon was an effective way to enhance the cycling stability of batteries. Sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) are considered one of promising candidates for economic and safe energy-storage devices, owing to its low cost and activity of sodium [108]. Sakaushi et al. reported a kind of porous, covalent triazine-based frameworks (BPOE) through ionothermal reaction of p-dicyanobenzene and ZnCl2 in quartz ampules at 400 °C for 40 h, which showed the sheet-like morphology with ∼300 nm wide and a thickness of ∼4 nm, confirming by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (Fig. 7 a). This short-range-ordered 2D polymeric framework constituted by aromatic rings brings them adjustable electronic properties and controllable semiconducting features, giving high-performance electrochemical properties for SIBs system. Utilized as cathode materials, the charge–discharge curves of BPOE were measured at various current densities ranging from 0.01 A g–1 to 5.0 A g–1 in a working potential of 1.3–4.1 V versus Na/Na+ (Fig. 7c). BPOE was a bipolar material, which had a p-dopable region and n-dopable region that can be continuously and linearly connected. This property endowed BPOE with a wide working potential range, which contributed so much to its high energy density (Fig. 7b and d). As organic electrode, BPOE had a high specific power of 10 kW kg−1, specific energy of 500 W h kg−1, and 80% of its initial capacity retaining in half-cells over 7000 cycle life. The shuttle effect of polysulfide would cause the capacity fading of battery, which is restricted severely the application of Li–S battery [109]. Recently, 2D layered COFs are good choices as the polysulfide host to confine elemental sulfide into the pores of COFs and decrease the dissolution of polysulfides during charge/discharge process for remarkably advanced lithium-sulfur battery. However, the interaction between COF and polysulfides is still not strong enough to provide an extremely stable cycling performance. Choi and coworkers reported a new method to synthesis S-CTFs by using linear polysulfane derived from the ring opening polymerization of elemental sulfur at 400 °C as substitution of ZnCl2 to initiate the cyclotrimerization of 1,4-dicyanobenzene. Notably, polysulfide compounds were polymerized or inserted in the micropores of CTFs when framework was formed simultaneously (Fig. 8 a). S-CTF-1 exhibited a uniform bipyramidal shape morphology, attributing to the covalent triazine framework acting as a structural template for the accumulation of crystalline sulfur particles with homogeneous distribution, confirmed by energy-dispersive X-ray analysis (Fig. 8b). The well-distributed sulfur incorporated to the frameworks with open pore structure could maximize the utilization efficiency of sulfur, leading to a relatively high capacity and decrease the deposition of insoluble Li2S on the surface of electrode for stable cycling performance. The first discharge–charge voltage profiles of S-CTF-1 were fulfilled at 0.05 C (Fig. 8c), which was consistent with the previous studies of S8 cases [98,100,110–112]. The initial discharge/charge capacities were 670 mA h g−1 and 632 mA h g−1 with high exceptional ICE of 94.4%, resulting from well-organized framework without considerable defects and dangling groups, a stable interface with the electrolyte to limit the shuttling of polysulfide [23]. The cycling performance of S-CTF-1 was further measured at 1 C and 2 C, and capacities of S-CTF-1 retained 85.8% and 81.0%, respectively, of the initial capacities after 300 cycles (Fig. 8d). Such stable cycling performance was attributed to the robust sulfur cathode structure, in which sulfur was homogeneously distributed throughout the regular micropores within the triazine-based framework together with the C–S covalent links. 4 2D polymeric nanosheets Generally, synthesis of 2D conjugated polymers with periodic structures requires the appropriate building blocks with rigid conformation and reversible chemical linkages, which limits their construction and application in large quantity. Recently, the deposition of conjugated polymers on the 2D nanomaterials as templates, e.g. graphene, to form 2D nanosheets could be a facile strategy to preparation of 2D conjugated polymeric nanosheets with rational porous structures [61]. On the basis of quinone and anhydride functional groups, poly(anthraquinonyl sulfide) (PAQS) [106] and polyimide (PI) [114] are typically electroactive polymers as cathode materials for high performance LIBs (Fig. 9 a). However, their intrinsical poor conductivity results in relatively low rate performance. In order to deal with this drawback, Wang et al. prepared a kind of conjugated polymer-graphene 2D nanocomposites through in situ polycondensation of dichloroanthraquinone (DCAQ) or 1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (NTCDA) on the 2D functionalized graphene sheets (FGS) at high temperature, named PAQS-FGS and PI-FGS, respectively (Fig. 9b). CV results showed that polarization of 2D nanocomposites became smaller with the increasing of FGS loading, suggesting the increase of conductivity for ultrafast charge–discharge performance (Fig. 9c). To explore 2D nanocomposites as cathodes for LIBs, their electrochemical performance were characterized by galvanostatic charge–discharge tests of CR2016-type coin cells. The discharge capacity of PAQS-FGS-b (26 wt.% FGS) stabilized at 165 mA h g−1 could be achieved relative to PAQS capacity of 177 mA h g−1. Under the same test conditions, the utilization ratio of 95% for 2D nanocomposites was improved greatly. It was also notable that PAQS-FGS-b maintained a discharge capacity of 100 mA h g−1 even at 100 C, in which the whole discharge process only took 16 s (Fig. 9d). The similar improvement was also observed for PI-FGS. Remarkably, nanocomposite containing 2D graphene showed better LIB performance than that containing 1D carbon nanotubes. Graphene-directed synthetic approach to preparation of 2D sandwich-like conjugated porous polymers by various chemical reactions has been developed as a new avenue to obtain 2D redox-active polymeric nanosheets [116–118]. Feng et al. reported the synthesis of compact graphene-coupled porous polyaryltriazine-derived frameworks through the anionic polymerization of acrylonitrile on the graphene surfaces to form RGO-PAN. After thermal treatment with 1,4-dicyanobenzene (p-DCB),1,3-dicyanobenzene (m-DCB), and 1,2-dicyanobenzene (o-DCB), N-doped porous carbon nanosheets (G-PPF) was applied as cathode materials for LIBs (Fig. 10 a). CV of G-PPF-p-400–600 was measured at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 below and above the open-circuit voltage of 3 V versus Li/Li+ (Fig. 10b), which suggested that the electrode had either reversible p-type or n-type redox activity. This property provided a broad potential range for high capacity. G-PPF-p-400–600 had excellent rate capability of 135 mA h g−1 at a high current density of 15 A g−1, and the capacity exhibited an increasing trend as cycle process went from 50th cycle to 550th cycle (Fig. 10c). This remarkably cycling could be attributed to the abundant electroactive site well exposed by the porous structure, while the rate performance was result from the conductive graphene composition and short ion path provided by the porous polymer structure. For 2D sandwich-like conjugated porous polymers, the non-covalent interactions represent the popular protocol to the functionalization of 2D materials with conjugated polymers, such as polyacetylene, polythiophene, polypyrrole and polyaniline [120–123]. Feng et al. reported the synthesis of 2D mesoporous polypyrrole nanosheets (mPPy) by dual templates of octadecylamine (OTA) and polystyrene-b-poly(ethylene oxide) (PS-b-PEO) block copolymers. Upon template removal by extraction with solvents, 2D mPPy nanosheets were achieved with controlled pore sizes in the range of 6.8–13.6 nm and ultrathin thicknesses of 25–30 nm (Fig. 11 a and b). From the CV curves of the mPPy-1 nanosheets, the redox peaks at 2.5 V in the cathodic process and 2.7 V in the anodic process at the initial cycle were observed clearly (Fig. 11c). Even after 50 cycles, the peaks showed a slight variation, suggesting good cycling stability and high Coulombic efficiency of the mPPy-1 electrodes. The galvanostatic charge/discharge behavior of the mPPy-1 nanosheet based SIBs was examined at various current densities (Fig. 11d). The mPPy-1 electrode exhibited sloping charge and discharge curves, with a reversible discharge capacity of 123 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1, which was superior to those of many PPy-based cathode materials with various morphologies, such as nanoparticles and hollow spheres [124]. At current densities of 100, 150, 200, and 300 mA g−1, the mPPy-1 nanosheets delivered high discharge capacities of 107, 101, 90, and 75 mA h g−1, respectively. This good rate performance could be attributed to the conductive framework and uniform mesoporous structure for ion transfer. This performance of the mPPy-1 nanosheet-based electrodes was competitive with those of the latest cathode materials developed for Na-ion batteries, including Na0.6Cr0.6Ti0.4O2 (<75 mA h g−1) [125], Na3(VO1-x PO4)2F1+2x (110 mA h g−1) [126], and Na2MnP2O7 (90 mA h g−1). 5 Summary and outlook In this review article, we have summarized recent progress in alkali-metal-ion batteries by applying 2D organic materials as cathode electrodes. 2D organic materials have shown the promising advantages of high specific surface area, optional chemical structure, unique electrical/magnetic properties as well as controllable hierarchical structure, which have been emerging as the ideal functional materials for the application in energy storage and conversion. In this regard, design and construction of 2D organic materials with lithiation/delithiation redox reactions and highly reversible properties has been considered as novel cathode materials in alkali-metal-ion batteries. In comparison with traditional inorganic cathodes (e.g. LiCoO2 or LiFePO4), 2D organic cathodes, featuring tunable structures, light weight, flexibility, and good semiconducting properties, would be essential component for flexible and portable alkali-metal-ion batteries. As a consequence, the 2D organic cathodes, including 2D polyaromatic molecules, 2D covalent organic frameworks and 2D polymeric nanosheets, are rendered with various heteroatom functional groups exhibited very rich electrochemical properties, making them widely applicable for alkali-metal-ion batteries, containing lithium ion battery, lithium sulfur battery, lithium air battery and sodium ion battery. Although remarkable achievement have been made in alkali-metal-ion batteries regarding the discovery of novel 2D materials and corresponding technical improvements, there are some primary challenges still exist at the current stage as following: (1) developing 2D heteroatom-embedded organic materials with reversible lithiation/delithiation properties; (2) the improvement of cycling performance using 2D organic materials as cathodes; (3) controlling the hierarchical porous architecture of 2D organic materials through molecular self-assembly; (4) fabrication of flexible thin-film alkali-metal-ion batteries with high energy density. With these difficulties to be overcome, 2D organic materials as cathodes hold great promises for practical applications in alkali-metal-ion batteries and their related areas. Mater. 28 2016 8365 8370 Chao Zhang received his B.S. degree from Hefei University of Technology in June 2015. Then he joined Prof. Xinliang Feng's group at Shanghai Jiao Tong University and began master's studies in September 2015. He focuses on fabricated porous carbon materials and 2D materials for energy storage and conversion. Chenbao Lu received his B.S. degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology from Nanjing University of Technology in June 2014 and received master's degree from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in March 2017. Then he joined the group of Prof. Fan Zhang at Shanghai Jiao Tong University and began doctoral studies in April 2017. He focuses on fabricating 2D materials for energy storage and conversion. Fan Zhang received his B.Eng. degree in electrochemistry from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 1991, and his Ph.D. in organic chemistry from Jilin University in 2000. After more than 8 years of research experience in Germany and the United States, he was promoted to a research professor in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China. His research interest is organic π-conjugated functional materials for optoelectronics and energy conversion and storage. Feng Qiu received his B.Sc. and M.Sc. degrees from Taiyuan University of Technology, and obtained his Ph.D. degree from Shanghai Jiao Tong University. Then, He did his postdoctoral research at Shanghai Jiao Tong University under the supervision of Prof. Xinliang Feng and Prof. Fan Zhang. He joined Shanghai Institute of Technology as a lecturer in 2015. His current research interests focus on the controlled preparation of functional polymers and their applications in electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Xiaodong Zhuang received his B.S.E. (2006) and Ph.D. (2011) degrees from East China University of Science and Technology. Then, he carried out his postdoc research at Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU), Max Planck Institute for Polymer Research (MPIP) and Dresden University of Technology (TUD). He became a research group leader at TUD from 2015. He has received professor position from SJTU and “NSFC Excellent Youth Funding” since 2017. His main research interest includes 2D soft materials, e.g. 2D conjugated polymers, 2D coordination polymer frameworks, 2D porous carbons, and their 2D hybrids, for optoelectronics and energy storage and conversion. Xinliang Feng, after obtaining his master's degree in organic chemistry from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in March 2004, joined the group of Prof. K. Müllen at the MPIP and obtained his Ph.D. in April 2008. He became a group leader at MPIP in December 2007. Since June 2010, he has been a professor at Shanghai Jiao Tong University and became a distinguished group leader at MPIP in 2012. In August 2014, he became a chair professor at Dresden University of Technology. His current scientific interests include graphene, two-dimensional nanomaterials, organic conjugated materials, and carbon-rich molecules and materials for electronic and energy-related applications.

coredata.dc:description: With the increasing demand for large-scale battery systems in electric vehicles (EVs) and smart renewable energy grids, organic materials including small molecules and polymers utilized as electrodes in rechargeable batteries have received increasing attraction. In recent years, two-dimensional (2D) organic materials possessing planar layered architecture exhibit optional chemical modification, high specific surface area as well as unique electrical/magnetic properties, which have been emerging as the promising functional materials for wide applications in optoelectronics, catalysis, sensing, etc. Integrating with high-density redox-active sites and hierarchical porous structure, significant achievements in 2D organic materials as cathode materials for alkali-metal-ion batteries have been witnessed. In this review, the recent progress in synthetic approaches, structure analyses, electrochemical characterizations of 2D organic materials as well as their application in alkali-metal-ion batteries containing lithium ion battery (LIB), lithium sulfur battery (LSB), lithium air battery (LAB) and sodium ion battery (SIB) are summarized systematically, and their current challenges including cycling stability and electron conductivity for cathode materials in battery fields are also discussed.
